answers.answer: c. 26 seconds.

answers.answer: d. 13 seconds.

question: QUESTION: 005  (1.00)   During a reactor startup, the count rate is increasing on a straight line on a logarithmic scale, with no rod motion.  This means that:

answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE: R. R. Burn, Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, page 5-25.

answers.answer: b. the reactor is critical and the count rate increase is due to source neutrons.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE: R. R. Burn, Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, page 5-25.

answers.answer: c. the reactor is subcritical and the count rate increase is due to source neutrons.

question: QUESTION: 006  (1.00)   A 1/M curve is being generated as fuel is loaded into the core.  After some fuel elements have been loaded, the count rate existing at that time is taken to be the new initial count rate, Co.  Additional elements are then loaded and the inverse count rate ratio continues to decrease.  As a result of changing the initial count rate:

answers.answer: a. criticality will occur with the same number of elements loaded as if there were no change in the initial count rate.
answers.feedback: Correct. REFERENCE: R. R. Burn, Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, page 5-18.

answers.answer: b. criticality will occur earlier (i.e., with fewer elements loaded.)
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE: R. R. Burn, Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, page 5-18.

answers.answer: c. criticality will occur later (i.e., with more elements loaded.)
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE: R. R. Burn, Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, page 5-18.

answers.answer: d. criticality will be completely unpredictable.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE: R. R. Burn, Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, page 5-18.

answers.answer: a. Delayed neutrons are more likely to cause fission after they become thermalized because they thermalize more quickly than prompt neutrons.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE: R. R. Burn, Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, page 3-27.

answers.answer:
b. Delayed neutrons take longer to thermalize because they are born at a higher average energy
than prompt neutrons.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE: R. R. Burn, Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, page 3-27.

answers.answer: c. Delayed neutrons increase the average neutron generation time.
answers.feedback: Correct. REFERENCE: R. R. Burn, Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, page 3-27.

answers.answer: d. Delayed neutrons are produced some time after prompt neutrons and make up the majority of neutrons produced by fissions.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE: R. R. Burn, Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, page 3-27.

QUESTION: 020  (1.00)

answers.answer: a. The number of neutrons gained per generation doubles for each succeeding generation.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE: R. R. Burn, Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, page 3-16.

answers.answer: b. A constant neutron population is achieved when the total number of neutrons produced in one generation is equal to the number of source neutrons added in the next generation.
answers.feedback: Correct. REFERENCE: R. R. Burn, Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, page 3-16.

answers.answer: c. For equal reactivity additions, it requires less time for the equilibrium neutron population to be reached.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE: R. R. Burn, Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, page 3-16.

answers.answer: d. When the indicated count rate doubles, the margin to criticality has been reduced by approximately one-half.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE: R. R. Burn, Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, page 3-16.
